questions.text: Sugar exhibits various forms of isomerism. Which of the following is not true about glucose sugar?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

In aqueous solution, glucose predominantly exists in its cyclic pyranose form (a six-membered ring). After dissolving, mutarotation occurs-an interconversion between the alpha (α) and beta (β) anomers at the anomeric carbon (C1).

  • α-D-glucopyranose: the -OH group on C1 is axial (down)
  • β-D-glucopyranose: the -OH group on C1 is equatorial (up) → more stable

Because the β-anomer is sterically more stable, it is present in higher proportion.

Actual distribution in solution:

  • ~62% β-D-glucopyranose
  • ~38% α-D-glucopyranose

Explanation of other options:

D or L form of a sugar is determined by the -OH/-H orientation on the carbon before the terminal alcohol (Option A): The D or L configuration of glucose depends on the orientation of the -OH group on the chiral carbon farthest from the carbonyl group (carbon 5 in glucose).

In solution, glucose is dextrorotatory, so glucose is called dextrose (Option B): Glucose rotates plane-polarised light to the right and is therefore dextrorotatory-commonly known as dextrose in clinical settings.

Crystalline Glucose is alpha-D-glucopyranose (Option C): In the crystalline form, glucose predominantly exists as α-D-glucopyranose, a six-membered ring (pyranose).

questions.text: Starch is an important dietary constituent of food. Which of the following sentences is not correct about starch?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

The statement that "Amylose is a soluble branched structure and amylopectin is an insoluble branched structure" is incorrect.

Starch is a homopolysaccharide composed entirely of glucose units linked by α-glucosidic bonds; hence, it is also called a glucan (or glucosan). It is a major dietary carbohydrate found in cereals, potatoes, legumes, and vegetables.

Starch consists mainly of two components:

  • Amylose (13-20%): A soluble, unbranched helical polymer with α-1,4 glycosidic bonds.
  • Amylopectin (80-87%): An insoluble, branched polymer with α-1,4 bonds in linear chains and α-1,6 bonds at branch points.

Explanation of other options:

Homopolysaccharides made up only of glucose (Option A): Starch is a homopolysaccharide, meaning it is composed of only one type of monomer: glucose.

Mixture of Amylose 15-20% and Amylopectin 80-85% (Option B):

  • Starch is made up of two components:
    • Amylose: linear, makes up about 15-20%
    • Amylopectin: branched, makes up about 80-85%
  • These percentages can vary slightly by source (e.g., rice, corn, potatoes), but the range is accurate.

Also called glucan or glucosan (Option D): The term glucan refers to a polysaccharide composed entirely of glucose units, which applies to starch. Glucosan is a less common term, but it also refers to glucose polymers.

questions.text: All of the following sugars give a Benedict's test positive except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Sucrose – Does not give a positive Benedict's test

  • Disaccharide of glucose + fructose
  • No free anomeric carbon → both involved in glycosidic bond (α1→β2 linkage)
  • Non-reducing sugar

Benedict's test is used to detect reducing sugars, which have a free aldehyde or keto group.

In alkaline solution, these groups can reduce Cu²⁺ to Cu⁺, forming a brick-red precipitate of copper(I) oxide (Cu₂O).

Explanation of other options:

Lactose (Option B): A reducing disaccharide (β1→4 linkage); the glucose unit has a free anomeric carbon, allowing it to reduce Cu²⁺

Glucose (Option C): A monosaccharide with a free aldehyde group (in open-chain form); gives a positive Benedict’s test.

Fructose (Option D): A ketose, but under alkaline conditions, it isomerizes to glucose/mannose (aldoses) and gives a positive Benedict’s test.

questions.text: Which of the following are enantiomers:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Enantiomers are non-superimposable mirror images of each other.
  • They have opposite configurations at all chiral centres.
  • In sugars, D- and L-forms are enantiomers, differing in the configuration around the penultimate carbon (second-last carbon in the chain).
  • The D/L system is based on the configuration of the chiral carbon furthest from the carbonyl group.
  • Examples of Enantiomers
    • D Glucose and L Glucose
    • D Fructose and L Fructose
    • D Mannose and L Mannose
    • D-Glyceraldehyde and L-Glyceraldehyde

Explanation for the answer:

D-Galactose is an epimer of D-glucose at the 4th carbon.

  • Epimers are diastereomers that differ in configuration at only one specific chiral carbon (excluding the anomeric and penultimate carbons).
  • For aldohexoses like glucose, the common chiral centres are C-2, C-3, C-4, and C-5.
  • So, if two sugars differ only at one of these positions, they are epimers.
  • Epimers of Glucose:
    • 2nd Epimer of Glucose - Mannose
    • 3rd Epimer of Glucose - Allose
    • 4th Epimer of Glucose - Galactose.

questions.text: D galactose and D mannose are?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Diastereomers are stereoisomers that are not mirror images.
  • They differ at one or more (but not all) chiral centres.
  • D-Galactose and D-Mannose differ at two chiral centres (C-2 and C-4) → They are diastereomers of each other.

Explanation of other options:

Enantiomers (Option A):

  • These are non-superimposable mirror images.
  • Enantiomers differ at all chiral centres.
  • Example: D-Glucose vs L-Glucose
  • D-Galactose and D-Mannose are not mirror images of each other → Not enantiomers.

Anomers (Option C):

  • Anomers differ in configuration only at the anomeric carbon (C-1 in aldoses)
  • Example: α-D-Glucose vs β-D-Glucose
    → D-Galactose and D-Mannose differ at multiple carbons and not at the anomeric carbon alone.
    → Not anomers.

Epimers (Option D):

  • Epimers differ at only one chiral centre.
  • Example: D-Glucose vs D-Mannose (C-2 epimers), D-Glucose vs D-Galactose (C-4 epimers)

D-Galactose and D-Mannose differ at two carbons (C-2 and C-4) → not epimers

Explanation:

  • Sucrose is a disaccharide made up of glucose + fructose, linked via a glycosidic bond (α1→β2).
  • The enzyme that hydrolyses sucrose into glucose and fructose is called:
    • Invertase (commonly used name)
    • Also known as Sucrase (especially in human intestinal enzymes)
  • The hydrolysis of sucrose changes the optical rotation of the solution:
    • Sucrose: +66.5° (dextrorotatory)
    • Glucose: +52.5°
    • Fructose: −92° (levorotatory)
  • The resulting mixture (glucose + fructose) has a net negative rotation, so the plane of polarised light is inverted; hence, "invert sugar."

Explanation of other options:

Amylase (Option B): Breaks down starch (amylose/amylopectin) into maltose and dextrins-not active on sucrose.

Sucrose phosphorylase (Option C): Catalyzes phosphorolysis (not hydrolysis) of sucrose - more relevant in some bacterial systems.

Saccharase (Option D): Outdated or alternate term sometimes used interchangeably, but Invertase is the classical and more widely accepted name.

questions.text: Which of the following compound is a fructosan?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • A fructosan is a homopolysaccharide made up only of fructose units.
  • The fructose monomers are typically linked by β(2→1) glycosidic bonds.
  • Inulin (Fructosan)
    • Homopolysaccharide of Fructose in β 2 → 1 linkage
    • Found in the roots of dahlias, chicory, onion, garlic, and dandelions
    • Belongs to a class of fibres
    • Readily soluble in water
    • Used in the clearance test to determine GFR
    • Not hydrolysed by human digestive enzymes.

Explanation of other options:

Fructose (Option A): It is a monosaccharide and hence not a fructan

Chitin (Option B): Homopolymer of N-acetylglucosamine, not fructose

Cellulose (Option C): Homopolymer of glucose, with β(1→4) linkages

questions.text: All of the following statements about optical isomers of carbohydrates are true except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sucrose itself is dextrorotatory (+66.5°)
  • On hydrolysis, it yields:
    • D-Glucose (+52.5°)
    • D-Fructose (−92°)
  • The strong levorotation of fructose dominates, so the final mixture is levorotatory
  • This change in optical rotation from positive to negative is why it's called invert sugar → Hence, after hydrolysis, sucrose is not dextrorotatory- it becomes levorotatory

Explanation of other options:

D-Glucose is dextrorotatory, but D-Fructose is levorotatory (Option A): D-Glucose rotates plane-polarised light to the right (+52.5°) → hence called Dextrose. D-Fructose, despite being a D-isomer, rotates light to the left (−92°)

Monosaccharide with no asymmetric carbon atom -Dihydroxyacetone (Option B): Dihydroxyacetone is the simplest ketose. Structure: CH₂OH-CO-CH₂OH. No chiral (asymmetric) carbon atoms, so no optical activity

An equimolar mixture of optical isomers that has no net rotation of plane-polarised light is called a racemic mixture (Option C): A racemic mixture contains equal amounts of dextrorotatory (+) and levorotatory (−) enantiomers. Their optical activities cancel out, giving no net rotation

questions.text: Osazone is formed by all of the following compounds except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An osazone is a crystalline derivative formed when a reducing sugar reacts with excess phenylhydrazine under heating.
  • Reaction occurs mainly at C-1 and C-2 of the sugar molecule.
  • Oxazones are insoluble and have distinct crystal shapes under the microscope.
  • Only reducing sugars can form osazones. These include:
    • Glucose (aldohexose) (Option A ruled out)
    • Fructose (ketohexose-becomes enediol under reaction conditions) (Option B ruled out)
    • Mannose (aldohexose) (Option C ruled out)
    • Lactose, maltose, etc.
  • Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar.
    • Its anomeric carbons (C-1 of glucose and C-2 of fructose) are involved in the glycosidic bond.
    • This prevents the formation of the free aldehyde or keto group needed for osazone formation.

Explanation:

Heparin is NOT a Proteoglycan:

  • Proteoglycans = Core protein + One or more GAG chains (like heparan sulfate).
  • Heparin does not contain a protein core, so it's not a proteoglycan.

Instead, it is a free-standing glycosaminoglycan.

Heparin is the following:

  • Glycosaminoglycan (GAG) (Option A ruled out):
    • Heparin is a sulfated GAG.
    • Composed of repeating disaccharide units: glucosamine and iduronic acid.
    • Functions mainly as a natural anticoagulant.
  • Polysaccharide (Option B ruled out):
    • GAGs like heparin are heteropolysaccharides (i.e., made from more than one type of sugar).
    • They are long chains of sugar units → hence polysaccharides.
  • Carbohydrate (Option D ruled out):
    • Polysaccharides are complex carbohydrates.
    • So, by definition, heparin is a carbohydrate.

Explanation:

  • Glycogenin is a protein
  • 37K Da protein

Key Functions of Glycogenin:

  • Acts as a primer for glycogen synthesis.
  • Catalyzes the attachment of 7 glucose residues from UDP-glucose to its own tyrosine residue.
  • The glucose units are linked by α-1,4-glycosidic bonds.
  • Once this initial chain is formed, glycogen synthase can take over and elongate the glycogen molecule.
  • Glycogenin remains embedded in the center of the growing glycogen granule.

Explanation of other options:

Polysaccharide (Option B): Glycogen itself is a branched polysaccharide of glucose; glycogenin is the protein nucleus on which that polysaccharide is built.

Lipid (Option C): Glycogenin does not have a structural or metabolic role involving lipids; it is entirely protein-based.

Glycosaminoglycan (Option D): GAGs are extracellular, unbranched sugar chains (e.g., hyaluronan); glycogenin is an intracellular protein primer, unrelated in structure or function.

questions.text: Complex polysaccharides are converted to glucose and absorbed by the help of:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Polysaccharides like starch are first partially digested by salivary and pancreatic amylase → breaking them into smaller oligosaccharides and disaccharides.
  • Final digestion to monosaccharides (like glucose) occurs in the small intestine via disaccharidases on the brush border.

● Role of Sucrase:

  • Sucrase-isomaltase complex is a brush border enzyme.
  • It hydrolyses sucrose → glucose + fructose.
  • Also involved in the final step of carbohydrate digestion, assisting in converting disaccharides into absorbable monosaccharides.

Explanation of other options:

Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase (Option A): Active transport of ions; not involved in digestion.

Enterokinase (Option C): Activates trypsinogen (protein digestion).

Carboxypeptidase (Option D): A pancreatic enzyme that removes amino acids from the carboxyl end of peptides (also involved in protein digestion).

questions.text: Which of the following biologically important glycosaminoglycans are present in the umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyaluronic Acid (HA):

  • A non-sulfated glycosaminoglycan (GAG).
  • Composed of repeating disaccharide units of:
    • Glucuronic acid (GlcUA)
    • N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc)
  • Form very large, highly hydrated polymers.

Functions and Locations:

  • Found widely in the extracellular matrix (ECM) of connective tissues.
  • Highly concentrated in:
    • Umbilical cord
    • Synovial fluid (joints)
    • Vitreous humour (eye)
    • Skin
    • Cartilage and embryonic tissues

Biological Roles:

  • Hydration and resilience of tissues.
  • Facilitates cell migration, especially during:
    • Morphogenesis (embryonic development)
    • Wound healing
  • Helps loosen the ECM by attracting water → promoting cell movement.

Explanation of other options:

Heparan Sulfate (Option A): Found in basement membranes, cell surfaces

Heparin (Option B): Found in mast cell granules (anticoagulant)

Keratan Sulfate (Option D): Found in cornea, cartilage

questions.text: Which of the following biologically important glycosaminoglycans are present in the Cornea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratan sulfates consist of repeating Gal-GlcNAc disaccharide units containing sulfate attached to the 6 position of GlcNAc or occasionally of Gal.

  • Keratan sulfate I was originally isolated from the cornea, while keratan sulfate II came from cartilage.
  • In the eye, they lie between collagen fibrils and play a critical role in corneal transparency. Changes in proteoglycan composition found in corneal scars disappear when the cornea heals.

Explanation of other options:

Heparan Sulphate (Option A): Found in cell surfaces, basement membranes, and extracellular matrix (ECM). Involved in cell signalling and filtration

Keratan Sulphate II (Option B): Found in cartilage, intervertebral discs, and loose connective tissues. Structurally similar to KS I but not located in the cornea

Hyaluronic Acid (Option C): Found in the vitreous humour of the eye, synovial fluid, skin, and umbilical cord

questions.text: Which of the following glycosaminoglycans plays an important role in charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Heparan Sulphate:

  • A glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found on cell surfaces and in basement membranes.
  • Structurally similar to heparin, but with:
    • Fewer N-sulfates
    • Predominant uronic acid: glucuronic acid (GlcUA)
  • Present in proteoglycan form, often attached to core proteins that span the plasma membrane.

Role in Kidney (Glomerulus):

  • Located in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) of the kidney.
  • The GBM contains:
    • Heparan sulfate
    • Type IV collagen
    • Laminin
  • Heparan sulfate contributes to the negative charge of the GBM.
  • This charge barrier prevents filtration of negatively charged proteins, such as albumin.
  • Thus, it plays a crucial role in the charge selectivity of the glomerular filtration barrier.

Explanation of other options:

Keratan Sulfate (Option B): Found in cartilage and cornea; not involved in glomerular filtration.

Hyaluronic Acid (Option C): A non-sulfated GAG; found in synovial fluid and vitreous humor; lacks charge barrier role in the kidney.

Chondroitin Sulfate (Option D): Found in cartilage and connective tissue; does not contribute significantly to glomerular charge selectivity.

questions.text: Which of the following confirmatory test is used for detection of ketose sugar?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Seliwanoff's Test:

  • A specific test used to differentiate ketoses from aldoses.
  • Based on dehydration of sugars by concentrated HCl → forms furfural derivatives.
  • In the presence of resorcinol, ketoses produce a deep red colour rapidly.
  • Aldoses may react slowly and produce a light pink colour (if at all).

Explanation of other options:

Barfoed's Test (Option A): Purpose: Distinguishes monosaccharides from disaccharides. Principle: Monosaccharides reduce copper ions in an acidic medium faster.

Molisch Test (Option C): Purpose: General test for all carbohydrates. Principle: Carbohydrates form purple/violet rings with α-naphthol and sulfuric acid.

Fehling's Test (Option D): Purpose: Detects reducing sugars (e.g., glucose). Principle: Reduction of Cu²⁺ → Cu⁺ with formation of red precipitate.
